Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2015 06:44AM SuC wrote: it is variable. I was 48 when I had my mastectomy and it took longer than I thought. I was back at work after 6 weeks but still sore. My second (prophylactic) mastectomy was far easier and I was back to normal pretty well by 4 weeks. The first time I had had a partial mastectomy which did not get clear margins, followed 10 days alter by a full mastectomy. This is maybe why I took so much longer first time. Also the psychology was different for the second one as I hadn' t just been diagnosed with cancer so was I a far better mental space. Make sure she does her exercises - she should get told which ones to do. These are really important for getting full movement back. I found that you could feel the difference day by day. Hope your Mum goes well

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2015 08:44AM SuC wrote: micro mets appear to be different to mets - more an example of the lymph nodes doing the job they are meant to do and stopping the cancer. I didn't have chemo or radio for my micromet - just tamoxifen. I had seven nodes out in total, just one micromet. Risks are close to having no mets.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2014 05:57AM SuC wrote: my surgeon didn't believe in leVing drains in for more than 2 days so I went home without drains both times. Very happy with this. Had minor seromas of 40 ml which required 2x aspirations over 3 weeks but that was all. It meant when I left hospital I didn't feel like so much of a patient
